Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 09:41AM dragonfly1 wrote: Hi everyone-I'm on the June Rads forum too and I don't post very often. I just wanted to encourage everyone that may be reading that sometimes Rads goes very smoothly. I had #26 of 33 today (28+5 boosts). My RO believes in using Aloe only unless there is skin breakdown. I've been using Aloe 3x/day and I have no change in skin color other than my nipple being slightly darker than the untreated one. The fatigue is definitely increasing but is manageable and I'm continuing to work full-time with no problem. I know that everyone responds differently but I hope it is encouraging to know that for some people Rads is not too bad. I consider myself blessed because chemo was awful for me and I think I was due for a break:)
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc
July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2011 10:31AM dragonfly1 wrote: Newatthis: During my consultation the RO mentioned that rads can cause swelling or shrinking of the breast and that there is no way to predict an individual's response. She also said that there is no way to tell whether the effect will be lasting but that swelling should go down after rads (shrinking, on the other hand may not go away according to my RO but didn't sound like it would be significant).
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 04:48AM dragonfly1 wrote: I asked my RO about sun exposure. She said no sun directly to the radiated area during Rads and for 6 months after Rads is over and then go back to using high SPF sunscreen. I've been in the sun a lot during Rads but I'm wearing a rash guard/sunscreen shirt to cover everything when I'm on a boat or swimming. I have 3 more boosts and my skin has just turned a light tan color in one corner of the Rads field and the nipple is darker on the treated side but otherwise no skin changes and all is well. I'm grateful.
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2011 11:21AM dragonfly1 wrote: I'm one of the people who was told not to use anything except Aloe 2-3x/daily. The RO and nurse said not to use any creams or anything else unless I begin to have a problem and then they will tell me what to use...I had #15 today and so far no problems, not even pink yet...it's hard to say why some of us react more than others.
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: May 10, 2012 05:08AM dragonfly1 wrote: wasgij96 Are you ER+/PR+/Her2+? If so, please join us on the thread called "Triple Positive". We can answer questions you have as you go through treatment and provide a lot of support. The standard treatment for Triple Positive is TCH (Taxotere/Carboplatin + Herceptin). Best Wishes!

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2011 10:27AM dragonfly1 wrote: BlueWillowSkys Thanks for starting the June Rads thread Hello June Rad ladies, I just finished TC chemo on Tues and still have Herceptin until February. I've already had my rads consulation and found out that I'll have my rads simulation/tattoos on June 16th and then start 33 rads on June 20th including 5 boosts. I'm dreading rads during the terrible heat of the summer on Long Island but I'll manage. I was able to work during chemo in spite of awful side effects so I know I can get through this too. My RO is telling me that I should go bra-less on my weekends and that it's ok to wear 100% cotton wireless bra on my work days. I had a hard time finding them but eventually found some reasonably priced ones from Jockey online but they only have sizes for A/B cups (so if you fit that description you are in luck-$20 each and the third one is free...) Just for fun: I noticed that the previous rad threads came up with the idea to buy the same number of lottery scratch off tickets for the number of treatments they have so that they can count off the days and have a little fun/win some money (hopefully) at the same time. I'm planning to do that as well and thought I'd share the idea for all of us who are beginning or rads journey...

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2011 12:26PM dragonfly1 wrote: Carberry I've had blonde highlighted hair for years but I think I'm going to go with my natural color for a while since this is a good opportunity. I'm rather surprised at the amount of gray that's coming in (I just turned 42) so I may need to do something about that! I've done so many things with my hair over the years. When I met my DH 9 years ago I had short spiked hair so luckily the short hair is not too much of an adjustment for me. He prefers it long-we'll see... Lago I know what you mean about the color change. Although the hair on my head seems to be my natural color, my eyebrows (what's left of them) have a lot of reddish brown in them-weird! My eyelashes are almost completely gone now. I've been using eyeliner to create some definition around my eyes. Otherwise, I just look ghostly. I had one very insensitive colleague who decided that she needed to comment on my loss of eyebrows and eyelashes. She said, "well it does make you look rather pale-you know, alien-like". I think she could have kept that to herself. Well, I have a great sense of humor and so does DH, so he took this pic of me with the fish-eye lense on our camera-Ha! You have to laugh...we laughed until we were absolutely hysterical!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 04:29PM dragonfly1 wrote: Well, it's been a truly weird week. Here's another story that will make you laugh. So, I'm at work again today and I walked through the hospital lobby on my way to a meeting. What's up with this lobby anyway-I think I better start avoiding it altogether. Well, it turns out Joan Jett is visiting our VA today to spread holiday cheer to the veterans and staff. Wow! How exciting, right? And, as I walk by, one of the handlers stops me and a female staff member/veteran and says why don't we take your photo with Joan? Greaaaat! I obviously have mixed feelings about this and now I have a photo with Joan Jett and my much hated hair:) I'm sure it will end up on our VA website next:( So, here's my updated hair photo-sticking out on the side and too thick on top where I tried to flatten the curls-Am I in the twilight zone?  I couldn't download a bigger image-I'm at work and can't access the appropriate programs but trust me, it's a bad hair day. Go ahead, laugh with me. This week is getting funnier by the minute!

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 11:22AM dragonfly1 wrote: Everyone is looking amazing-hang in there and believe me, your hair WILL grow. In fact at just over 7 months PFC I'm beginning to wonder what to do with mine. The thickness and texture along with the wave/curl are making it grow in width/height more than length these days. I told my DH that I'm starting to look like Don King (no offense to him but that's not the look I'm going for) I'm resorting to a headband now to clamp some of the hair down in the front so that I don't have such huge hair on the top-this is really a challenge...

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 12:28PM - edited May 4, 2012 12:29PM by dragonfly1 I know this is off the subject of hair but I thought I'd post it here since it has to do with our appearance post-treatment. I had my port removed on April 9th so of course I have a red incision/scar and it always seems to be right along the collar of my shirt where you can see it. I've been very self-conscious about it and annoyed that I have to avoid wearing certain things. So I stopped by Ulta today and found the solution to the problem. They gave me a product called Dermablend (also used to cover tattoos). I bought the "cover cream" in my skin tone along with a clear "setting powder". It says it will last for up to 12 hours and is waterproof. It's a bit pricy but there's enough that I won't have to buy it again for a year (it was approx $30 for each). Thought this may help someone else who wants to cover a scar...Here's a photo after applying it:  Rt Lumpectomy/SNB 1/7/2011 TCHx6 (2/15-5/31/11), Herceptin x 1 year (done 1/18/12), Rads 28+5 (finished 8/8/11) BRCA 1/2 Neg, Now on Tamoxifen, My "jump for joy" http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5jUmLkbhHZE Diagnosis: 11/29/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 04:33PM dragonfly1 wrote: AEM47 My eyelashes and eyebrows recovered fairly quickly once they fell out. They began growing back in almost immediately. I'm at almost a year PFC and my eyebrows still don't grow. They are thinner and lighter than they were before they fell out. Here are some photos after having my hair cut and highlighted today-it desperately needed some shape and color. This is my second official haircut and I'm planning to let the top and sides keep growing. It takes a lot to tame the curls but I'm hoping it will get easier as it grows. I can't believe how short my bangs are after 11+ months of growth (that part of my hair has never been cut).  I'm just past 11 months PFC now...

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 08:16PM dragonfly1 wrote: Ksmatthews  I tried an at-home Keratin treatment too (mine was called Keratin Earth) and had the same result. It was great the day I used it but the straightening was gone the next time I washed my hair:( Oh well! By the way, I have been using a tiny 1/2" straightening iron that I found at Bed, Bath and Beyond. It's narrow enough to use on my short hair so I straighten it every day now. It takes me about 30 minutes to flatten all of it which is more time that I really want to spend but I'm much happier with how it looks after flat ironing the curl out.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 12:07PM dragonfly1 wrote: LisaGH I have a love/hate relationship with the wig too:) I'm so grateful that I can wear it to work and my patients/families/staff have no idea what I'm going through and I appreciate the ease of putting the wig on quickly and having perfect, styled, shiny hair every day. However, now that my real hair is growing, it's getting really hot under there and the wig is never 100% comfortable-it pinches sometimes in places... SpecialK NO new hair??? Are you sure? Maybe it's because your hair is so light and it's less obvious-let's go with that. My hair is so dark that it looks a lot like Lago's early pics. I'll try to post a pic soon. I have even coverage all over although the top/front started about 2 weeks after the back/sides so it's a little shorter. You can still see my scalp all over but I think with 6 more weeks it should fill in. I'm not using anything-just eating my fruits, veggies and protein during Rads. I'm too scatter-brained to keep up with any more meds at this point and I honestly think it's going to do whatever it wants anyway. What's happening with your eyelashes/eyebrows? Mine keep thinning but are mostly intact-not too noticeable.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 05:26PM dragonfly1 wrote: http://www.flickr.com/photos/61567341@N08/5947389509/ http://www.flickr.com/photos/61567341@N08/5947945024/ I don't know if I downloaded the links properly but hope they worked. This is my hair at almost 7 weeks PFC. I buzzed my hair 2 weeks after the last chemo to get rid of the weird, clear, sparse hair-so this is all new growth in the past 5 weeks. The front didn't start growing until 2 weeks after the sides and back (you can actually see a clear difference). My DH is away a lot and every time he returns home he is shocked at the difference even though I never think anything is happening:)

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2011 06:29PM dragonfly1 wrote: Carberry I'm sticking with my natural color for now. I was a blonde for a long time and loved the color but I think this is a great opportunity to go back to the real color for a while. It will be nice to have less maintenance. I actually went for a cut/trim today (after I posted the pics) to even things out-my husband's barber did it since I don't have much hair:) The back and sides were a lot longer because it had never been cut at all and it was getting a bit scruffy. I hated to lose some length but I think it looks more styled now and will grow more evenly. It was a quite funny experience-the barber was very sweet and kept fussing over every little detail which he had not been doing for the men before me. The place was packed and all the men looked so puzzled about me getting my hair cut (I'll tell you one thing, those men have the right idea-quick, easy and $20!!!)  Another thing to add to my list of firsts...

Someone mentioned a fur hat-yeah, that's it. Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 04:47PM dragonfly1 wrote: mkw1 Yes, I went back to my natural color-there's a little grey mixed in but I can live with it for now. I don't think I'll consider the expense of coloring it until it gets a lot longer and I've figured out what it's going to really do. Are other people still struggling with their eyebrows? Mine STILL aren't growing 8 months PFC and never have since chemo. I haven't ever lost any more but I haven't grown any new ones either. My left one took a beating and thinned to almost nothing-you can probably tell in the picture-my liner had worn off today so it looks a little pitiful. It's nice that I haven't plucked my eyebrows in 8 months but it seems a little weird. My eyelashes seemed to recover without a problem.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 06:59PM dragonfly1 wrote: Deniseday Yes, lots of us have had the fuzzy face stuff. I finally got it under control with a little device called a "Clio" trimmer that buzzes it off without actually shaving right to the skin-think battery operated miniature electric razor. I've done it twice and the fuzz is fully under control now (and is not growing back in dark in case you were worried).

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 03:45PM dragonfly1 wrote: Bonseye My eyebrows thinned during chemo but I didn't completely lose them. They thinned again 5 weeks PFC at the same time that all of my eyelashes fell out. It has always been easy to use powder to fill the eyebrows in. The eyelashes grew back quickly and I found that wearing eyeliner helped to define my eyes until they came back-no one ever noticed they were gone except me. Re: the eyebrow tattoos. I went to a Look Good Feel Better class by the American Cancer Society and they advised against it only because they said you don't know how much your skin will change as you age and if it droops/sags you could end up with eyebrows where you don't want them-yikes:(
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 01:46PM dragonfly1 wrote: So, I just got a phone call from our public affairs officer for the medical center saying he needs to take my photograph for our lobby-WHAT?!? I work for a Veterans hospital and apparently some mandate came out today from on high that they must post a photograph of the designated POW coordinator (me) in the lobby so that every visiting veteran and family will know who I am. I almost had a heart attack. My hair is at a very strange, unmanageable length-I'm completely unhappy with it right now and I'm trying to just tolerate it while it grows out. And now it will be immortalized in the hospital lobby:( Oh well, I asked him to hold off for a week while I figure out what to do with myself. Guess I better make a hair appt. It's almost funny...almost....
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 02:02PM dragonfly1 wrote: Carroll, I'm so sorry to hear about the loss of your mother-my heart goes out to you-big HUG. Update on my dilemma at work. One of my wonderful colleagues found this photo that was used in our department newsletter last year and emailed it to me this morning so that I could ask administration to use it instead of taking a current photo with my transitional hair that I hate right now. I will be much happier seeing this photo when I walk into the hospital every day. It's bad enough I have to look at this hair in the mirror every morning-I sure don't need a poster in the lobby too!!! Me before the BC nightmare began:   I'm 7 months PFC and I have about 1.5 inches on top and 2 inches in the back. It's dark (my normal color which I don't mind), curly, fuzzy and completely unruly. I'm really trying to like this new hair but I just don't. I really want my straight hair back. I keep hoping that added length will make it easier to deal with but I'm not sure...I have a hair appt on Tuesday and I'll post some pics after that...

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 06:51PM dragonfly1 wrote: Here's an update at 7 months PFC. I know how much the pics have helped me so maybe this will help someone else. I've only had it trimmed once (about 2 months ago) and I'm getting it cut tomorrow to try to shape it because it's beginning to get very "puffy" due to the thickness, body and curls. Big round hair is not the look I'm going for:)  I'm using a lot of gel, paste, wax, etc just to flatten it a bit. I thought it may be more helpful to post before I get it cut so you can see the actual length and curl at 7 months. The front and sides have definitely been the slowest to grow and the back is almost twice as long.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 04:08PM dragonfly1 wrote: I'm in the same situation I suppose. I'm not thrilled with the PFC hair either. The texture is weird and it's completely unmanageable. I'm about 6 months PFC and my hair isn't very long but is getting waves in it so I suppose it's going to curl. Like many have described, the front is taking its time growing so I have no bangs at all (although its deceiving because it seems to be curled up in a fuzzy mess). I have to wash my hair at night and sleep on it to flatten it and calm the frizz-nothing else works. If I wash it and go out (without sleeping on it) I look like a static ball. My best friend described my hair as being a little bit like a brillo pad (she's the only one who can be that honest with me and get away with it). So, I try to not look in the mirror much and keep hoping it will magically work itself out with more length!

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2011 05:54PM - edited Jul 26, 2011 05:57PM by dragonfly1  It's only been a week since the last hair growth pics but I'm playing around with photobucket to see what I can do so thought I'd post this anyway. I think people like my wig better than my real hair (probably because I never took much time to do anything with my real hair and the wig is perfectly styled every day:) Won't they be shocked when they see my super short dark hair in a few more weeks...I'll post more pics when I have more hair growth to share. It's growing relatively fast-even in the past week.   P.S. I'm not usually that shiny-Ha!Ha! that was a pic on the way to a whitewater trip in boiling heat in Costa Rica 2 months before I was diagnosed-Hmmm. wish I had that energy right now!

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 10:05AM dragonfly1 wrote: SpecialK Hi:) Yes, I work on Sundays so I'm always up early-I'm at the VA now getting ready  to do some inpatient work with veterans... My DH says the same thing i.e. to just go for it. He's so accepting and doesn't realize that not everyone sees me the way he does:) I'm smiling about your sideways wig during PT. I noticed that some women wore hats to their radiation appt. every day but I wore my wig because I was going straight to work. I wouldn't even take the wig off once I got in the back (where only the techs would see me) so I invariably had a hard time getting my head positioned and always seemed to have my wig off kilter when I went back into the changing room:)  I was just happy I was allowed to wear it. I've had such interesting experiences during this process. Once I was wearing a hat while waiting for a PET scan in a crowded waiting room. A woman was blatantly staring at me for the longest time. When the waiting room cleared out she walked over to me and quietly said, "I'm a survivor and I just wanted you to know that you'll be fine". I decided at that point that I should re-think the looks I get and just give people the benefit of the doubt. On the other hand, on a recent trial run going topless on a weekend, I had a woman staring at me and then she walked over and said "good for you, when my hair was growing back I couldn't even leave the house". Arghh! I know it was her issue but that's exactly what I mean by not wanting any attention and just wanting to blend in again...

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 11:18PM dragonfly1 wrote: Shore1 I had the relaxer put in my hair 2 weeks ago and I'm 13 months pfc. My hair is about 3 inches long now but has been trimmed 3 times. I wish I had known about the relaxer sooner. It has made my hair more manageable and it looks more like my pre-chemo hair so I'm much happier with it.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 01:12PM - edited Oct 13, 2011 01:13PM by dragonfly1 Wow! Everyone's hair looks great! The back of mine is growing much faster than the top and is beginning to curl now-don't know what I'll do with that because my hair is not normally curly. It's at a very awkward stage and is extremely frizzy/fuzzy all over and nothing seems to calm it down. It seems that the frizz is actually the ends beginning to curl. I look like some kind of cross between a brillo pad and carpet-Yikes! I don't care though because I'm so happy to have hair again. I was visiting my best friend over the weekend and as best friends do, she told me the truth:) She saw all that light baby fuzz on my cheeks and said "that has to go!" I had not known what to do with it because I was afraid to shave my face. Well, she showed me this thing called a "Clio" which is a small personal trimming device (size of a pen, uses a AAA battery) that you can buy at Target, Walgreens, Ulta, etc. It's amazing. It's like a tiny version of clippers and just buzzes the fuzz right off without actually shaving right to the skin-perfect! Just had to share...

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 03:51PM dragonfly1 wrote: Hi all-here's an updated photo at 8 months PFC. It seems that my hair is growing three times faster in the back than in the front or on top. I can't begin to create bangs because the hair just won't go that direction:) No amount of paste, wax, gel, etc can force it. I've just been drying it on a low setting and pulling the curl out as much as I can. The back is getting big loopy curls now and has a mind of its own (I don't know if you can see it in the pic but the bottom is one big rolled up curl:) This hair is a radically different texture than my old hair-I still call it brillo hair:) It's just not shiny like it used to be either. I'm hoping it begins to pick up speed growing now that I've finished Herceptin. I've only had it trimmed twice and the hairdresser dried it with a round brush into a big poofy helmet-ickkk! I prefer to just scrunch the waves/curls and let them be...

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 12:37AM dragonfly1 wrote: luv2trav: I'm having the same question about working. I had my lumpectomy/SNB on 1/7/11 and was able to go back to work after 4 days without any problem. I'm triple positive (ER+/PR+/Her2+) and will be meeting with the oncologist for the first time this Friday and I fully expect to get chemo and Herceptin because of the Her2. I work in a hospital (although it's adults only) but I'm a federal employee and we don't have access to short term disability as a result. I only have 4 weeks of sick leave so I would be forced to take leave without pay if I can't work. My hope is that I can work most of the time and just take days off as needed during each cycle because there is no way I can just take the next 4-5 months off completely. I know in a perfect world the oncologists would like us to take the time off but it's just not realistic sometimes. I'll post again to let you know how it works out because I'm guessing I'll start treatment fairly soon. Best wishes with your lumpectomy and a speedy recovery! Be sure to check out the treatment forum for triple positives when you get a bit closer to receiving treatment because it sounds like you are a triple positive as well-here is the link:

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 08:16PM dragonfly1 wrote: Benture25 I'm so sorry that you and your girlfriend are going through this-it's so overwhelming. It really does get easier once you have a specific plan and regain a sense of control.  Breast cancer is a shock and really turns your life upside down for a while. Have you gotten any more info from pathology or scans? Your initial post was a bit confusing. You seemed to indicate that there may be lymph node involvement-are they guessing from the pathology or an MRI? Usually lymph nodes are confirmed at the time of surgery with a sentinel node biopsy. You also mentioned grade 1 but also Her2+. That doesn't seem quite right because Her2+ tumors are usually high grade/aggressive (as in grade 2 or 3) and Her2+ almost always requires chemo even if it's small. I'm not sure a Her2+ tumor would be grade 1. If the oncologist said "slow growing and... might not need chemo" it sounds like it's not Her2+. The final staging will come from the surgical pathology-right now any staging is tentative. Keep us posted-we're here if you need to vent or ask questions. Sending a big HUG!!!
Posts.Title: SOOO many questions benture25 dragonfly1

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 10:27AM dragonfly1 wrote: Luv2trav: The consensus over on the taxotere/carboplatin/herceptin thread seems to be that days 3-5 following chemo can be the worst. I also get the sense from following that thread that once you have your first 3 week cycle of chemo you will have a good idea of how you will individually respond to the following cycles. I'm hoping for the best and that I can work it out with the job somehow. My normal work schedule at the hospital is Wed-Sun so I'll have to do some maneuvering to time it right...I'm ahead of you in starting treatment so I'll definitely let you know how it goes  I know you'll do well with the lumpectomy. Just take good care of yourself afterwards...I was sore for 2 days, felt great by day 3 and didn't even need the painkillers. When I returned to work the only thing I noticed was that I would get more tired than usual by the end of the day (that lasted for about a week). Waiting is the worst part of all of this-I hate it! I had to wait several weeks for my surgery and now I've been waiting 2 weeks for my oncology appt. Weeks feel like months when you are waiting to get things taken care of with BC!!! Hang in there...

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 04:20PM dragonfly1 wrote: loving-mother: I'm no expert as I was just diagnosed on 11/29 and I'm actually scheduled for my lumpectomy and SNB this week on 1/7. When my Gyn called me with the initial diagnosis he gave me the name of a general surgeon and told me to set up an appointment. Luckily I began asking everyone I know about this and was told NOT to go to a general surgeon but to instead find a breast surgeon who does these surgeries all the time. I was eventually able to find a breast surgeon and she is incredibly knowledgeable. She has a reputation for getting clean margins and for doing lots of SNBs. I agree with the other members that you should find a breast surgeon if you can. It's so hard to manage all of this when you are already overwhelmed with a new diagnosis but it really does start to get easier. In the first few weeks I felt like I was walking through a minefield. Being newly diagnosed during the holidays really sucks too! I found myself struggling with New Year's because all I could think was that 2011 is going to be a very hard year of surgery and treatment. I've also been told numerous times not to hesitate to get a second opinion. I think that's good advice considering what how much depends on what these doctors tell us. I'm going to be seeking out an oncologist now and I expect that I'll be seeking more than one opinion for sure since I'm ER+/PR+/HER+ and want to be sure I get the best possible treatment (and will likely be in treatment for a long time so I better like the oncologist I choose...) Anyway, every week it's getting a little bit easier so hang in there. We'll all get through it together.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125
Newly diagnosed and trying to keep it together Leighsa Joan811

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 08:16AM dragonfly1 wrote: seabeal I'm so sorry that you have to be here. We can all relate to your feelings. After well over a year of dealing with BC and treatment I've learned that this diagnosis creates significant fear and anxiety for you AND your family. I completely underestimated how much it was affecting my husband in the beginning because I was so angry and felt like "I" was the one going through it. Don't forget that he will be going through it too and he will be scared whether he says it or not-and often men don't express themselves well. I was pointed to a book called "Breast Cancer Husband: How to Support Your Wife (and Yourself) During Diagnosis, Treatment and Beyond" on Amazon. It's written by a husband who went through this. I bought it for my husband early on and I although he wouldn't say much, I would catch him reading sections now and then. Having said that, you will continue to get comments that are upsetting because unfortunately we've all been told for so long that if it's caught early we're ok to the point that people seem to think we're dealing with the common cold. As a result, our friends and family may be well-meaning but they say some stupid things that feel very minimizing and dismissive. I feel like I've spent the past year re-educating everyone that there is no cure and Stage I is wonderful but does not = safe. It simply gives me better odds at the outset. We still have cancer and it's dangerous at all stages. Meanwhile, keep communicating and get those feelings out. I had to come here to vent to the women who truly understood what I was going through-to ask my questions and express my fears during the tough times.  It really does get better. As soon as you have a treatment plan you will feel a sense of control and that helps. But I will never forget what my Breast Surgeon said: she told me that after a BC diagnosis, surgery and treatment (regardless of what combination you need) "it's a year of your life" meaning that you need that long to get through the process physically and emotionally. She was right.  Big HUG!
Posts.Title: What's next? seabeal sandik
Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 03:24PM dragonfly1 wrote: Cyndesign You are a wonderful friend for asking! I agree with MDG. My friends who have just listened have been the most helpful and it really irks me too when people say "stay strong" (I guess because it goes without saying and do I really have a choice?) I think sometimes we really just need to vent about how rough we feel and other days we will focus on being positive but either way it's really tough going through all this treatment while life just continues on around us. 1. Several of my friends have been sending me cards at various times throughout treatment which is really encouraging. I've had friends mail me boxes of homemade cookies, funny videos, a pillowpal (for my naps), PJs (button-up top for after surgery). My best friend made CDs like the "kick chemo's ass mix"...little things really make you smile when you are going through this:) As far as food, I snacked on animal crackers. "Sunsweet Ones" individually wrapped prunes and dried apricots were really helpful (chemo causes constipation sometimes). My sister the nurse sent me thermacare heatwraps to pamper myself when I was aching (bone pain from shots given during chemo) and some gentle Aveeno bubble bath. Something else that I have since discovered that would be a great gift is a "Chillow" because chemo can put you into menopause and cause hot flashes and a chillow is a cooled mat for your pillow. 2. Two books that have been so helpful: "What To Eat During Cancer Treatment: 100 Great Tasting , Family-Friendly Recipes to Help You Cope". The book is actually broken into chapters based upon side effects such as nausea, weight loss, taste alteration, etc. and helped me a lot during chemo. I highly recommend the Shepherds pie:)  If your friend is married, the other book that was wonderful is "Breast Cancer Husband: How to Help Your Wife (and Yourself) During Diagnosis, Treatment and Beyond" by Marc Silver . It was written by a man whose wife had breast cancer and is an easy read. My husband (who never reads) actually read it and found it very helpful in understanding what I am going through...Both books are on Amazon 3. A dear friend of mine recommended that I set up a "Caringbridge" webpage. It's free and you can make it private so that only your friends/family can view it. Caringbridge is for those with longterm health conditions. It has turned out to be an amazing support. Essentially, you write entries and it will alert the list of designated friends at which point they can write comments of support in your guestbook. I really like it because it's a private place to express anything and everything that I'm going through and I can even post pictures. You can keep your Caringbridge page going as long as you want. For me, it's a better alternative than a public blog or sharing things on facebook where I have a mixed group of friends and some don't know... Many of my friends have wanted to do something for me at times when I didn't actually need anything except their friendship. It's hard to watch someone suffering and not be able to do anything. At those times, I told them that just spending time with me was really all I needed. Taking a short walk with me, sitting on my deck with me, watching tv, etc. You are already a wonderful friend just for asking:)

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 10:43AM dragonfly1 wrote: Deb267 Wow-what a small world! I work for the VA too (in a medical center on Long Island)! I'm a social worker in the ER and on inpatient medicine. I work evenings/weekends in order to provide social work coverage during the hours when the rest of my service is not here. The staff at my VA have been incredibly supportive too-great group of people:) And my sister is a nurse at another VA facility in MA! If you want to add your ER/PR/Her2 info, etc. just click on your profile name at the top of the screen and it will take you to your profile page. Then just start filling in the diagnosis information and save it when you are done. It will start appearing on your future posts. I have not had the cording/lymphedema issue but it is a common risk after surgery. I know that there are separate forums dedicated to it if you search (under Lymphedema). I think the most important thing is that if you see a PT, make sure they are certified to work with cording/lymphedema. I found this link about axillary cording:   http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Cording_and_Axillary_Web_Syndrome.htm and this one for finding a certified lymphedema therapist: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Finding_a_Qualified_Lymphedema_Therapist.htm Hope that helps a little bit. Good luck with your appointments next week!

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 01:56PM dragonfly1 wrote: sweetpea23 Your post caught my eye because we have a lot in common-I could almost have written your original post. I was diagnosed on my 2nd mammogram at age 41 which completely shocked me. I have no family history either and my BRCA 1/2 test was negative. I ended up with a 1.2 cm tumor that was ER+/PR+/Her2+ and was also told to throw my birth control pills away immediately. I chose a lumpectomy as well but ended up having to do chemo in addition to the Rads because of the Her2+ component.  It really does get easier with time. It's a terrible shock and really turns your world upside down for a while. I have found BCO to be a reliable source of information and a wonderful support. Ask any questions you have and vent when you need to-we all understand! Sending you a big cyber-hug:)
Posts.Title: 41 and just diagnosed w/ IDC sweetpea23 sweetpea23

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 05:04PM dragonfly1 wrote: CindyT I'm so sorry to hear about your diagnosis. It's a terrible shock in the beginning and there is no easy way to get your head around something like this. Trust those of us who are a little ways into the journey, it really does get better. Part of the problem is that you feel very overwhelmed and out of control in the beginning but once you have surgery and begin treatment you start to feel like you are regaining some control and thing settle down. Being ER+/PR+ is not a bad thing, (I'm 90%+ on both as well). It means that you have something to target if that makes sense. So, generally after surgery/chemo, etc. you take meds to block the hormones. As far as making a decision, take a deep breath and whatever you do, don't feel rushed. If there is anything I've learned in all of this it's that you have more time than you think. At the beginning I thought, "Oh no, I've got cancer, I have to do something quickly." Looking back, I realize now that I could have taken more time. I was so afraid that every minute, day, week was allowing the cancer to grow but even aggressive BC doesn't grow that fast. So, if you need more than one opinion, get it. If you require something like an oncotype test (in some cases it helps to determine if you are a good candidate for chemo) then wait for the results. Get all the information you need to make the best decision for you personally. Making the decision for lumpectomy vs. mastectomy is not always easy but I relied on the expertise of my BS who assured me that there is very little difference in recurrence rates between the two options. Sometimes a lumpectomy is not possible if the tumor is too large to get a good cosmetic result or there are multiple areas involved. Again, take the time you need to really weigh the options and decide what is best for you.    Cry when you need to-I'm not one to cry a lot but I was a basket case in those first few weeks and found myself waking up in the middle of the night, crying, wandering through the house aimlessly-totally out of character. This turns your world upside down. Trust me, it will get a lot better. Best wishes to you as you move forward-extending a big cyber hug to you:)
Posts.Title: Fear CindyT jazz3000

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2011 01:55PM - edited Dec 16, 2011 11:17AM by dragonfly1 Deb267 I know that your head is spinning with all of this and its very overwhelming. I'm so sorry that you are dealing with this. Let me see if I can clarify a little bit. I'm no expert but...it would help to know more about your estrogen, progesterone and Her2 status-are you + or - ? From the little bit of info you've provided, it's a good news/bad news situation (it's never all good news with BC is it?). Negative nodes is very good news because it means that the cancer did not spread to your lymph nodes. Grade 3 is not so good because it's "high" grade meaning the cells are highly disorganized and aggressive. However, grade 3/dividing cells will respond better to chemo. Finally, vascular invasion means that there is evidence of blood vessel involvement. The problem with BC is that it's sneaky and travels in more than one way (through the lymph nodes or the blood vessels). I have a feeling that chemo is being suggested for you based on the Grade 3 and vascular invasion because they will want to ensure that if any cells escaped, they kill them before they can establish themselves anywhere else. I remember looking at my oncologist in horror and saying "why in the world do I need chemo if I have clear margins and it's not in my lymph nodes?". She gently explained that for those of us with aggressive, high grade BC (even when it's early stage), they just don't have a way to determine if those cells got away and we can't take that chance. The other thing that can be really helpful is the Oncotype test-it's a genetic test that will give you a score that indicates your risk and can help you make a better decision about your need for chemo. If it comes back intermediate or high, you'll know for sure that chemo is necessary which is even more peace of mind. These decisions are never easy. I'm a year into treatment and please know that it really does get easier. You reach a point where it's less of a daily battle and you start to feel normal again. Do not feel rushed to make treatment decisions-you have time even though it may feel very urgent. Make sure that you feel comfortable with what you are doing. Edited to add: you asked about the timeframe for chemo-my understanding from what my MO told me is that it is recommended that you start chemo within 6-8 weeks of your surgery date for maximum effectiveness. Wishing you all the best!
Posts.Title: Vascular invasion nodes neg Deb267 dragonfly1
